content.value: Refrain from generating dynamic scripts, which can cause your Lua cache to grow and get out of control. Memory is consumed as scripts are loaded. If you have to use dynamic Lua scripts, then remember to track your Lua memory consumption and flush the cache periodically with a SCRIPT FLUSH, also do not hardcode and/or programmatically generate key names in your Lua scripts because it makes them useless in a clustered Redis setup.
Shorten key names to optimize memory usage. Though, in general, descriptive key names are always preferred, these large key names can eat a lot of the memory.

bigHashes.title: Shard big hashes to small hashes

content.value: If you have a hash with a large number of field-value pairs (> 5,000), and if each pair is small enough - break it into smaller hashes to optimize memory usage. Additionally, try using smaller or shortened field names.
l
Additionally, you can use RediSearch, designed to help address your query needs and supports a better development experience.
l
Learn more about how Search capability can help you via Tutorials in Workbench.

Redis supports multiple logical databases within an instance, though these logical databases are neither independent nor isolated in any other way and can freeze each other. Also, some modules do not support numbered databases as well.

Strings data type has an overhead of about 90 bytes on a 64-bit machine, so if there is no need for different expiration values for these keys, combine small strings into a larger hash to optimize the memory usage.
Also, ensure that the hash has less than hash-max-ziplist-entries elements and the size of each element is within hash-max-ziplist-values bytes.
l
Though this approach should not be used if you need different expiration values for String keys.
Several set values with IntSet encoding exceed the set-max-intset-entries. Change the configuration in reds.conf to efficiently use the IntSet encoding.
Though increasing this value will lead to an increase in latency of set operations and CPU utilization.
l
Run `INFO COMMANDSTATS` before and after making this change to verify the latency numbers.

If any value for a key exceeds hash-max-ziplist-entries, it is stored automatically as a Hashtable instead of a Ziplist, which consumes almost double the memory. So to save memory, increase the configurations and convert your hashtables to ziplist. The trade-off can be an increase in latency and possibly an increase in CPU utilization.
Hash field name also consumes memory, so use smaller or shortened field names to reduce memory usage.
If you use long lists, and mostly access elements from the head and tail only, then you can enable compression.

Set list-compression-depth=1 in redis.conf to compress every list node except the head and tail of the list. Though list operations that involve elements in the center of the list will get slower, the compression can increase CPU utilization.
l
Run `INFO COMMANDSTATS` before and after making this change to verify the latency numbers.
Avoid storing large strings, since transferring them takes time and consumes the network bandwidth. Large keys are acceptable only to read/write portions of the string.

zSetHashtableToZiplist.title: Convert hashtable to ziplist for sorted sets

content.value: Increase zset-max-ziplist-entries
l

If any value for a key exceeds zset-max-ziplist-entries, it is stored automatically as a Hashtable instead of a Ziplist, which consumes almost double the memory. So to save memory, increase the configurations and convert your hashtables to ziplist. The trade-off can be an increase in latency and possibly an increase in CPU utilization.

If you are using sets for existence checks or to eliminate duplicates, and you are ready to trade accuracy with speed and memory usage, consider using Redis probabilistic data structures to increase performance and decrease memory usage.

bigAmountOfConnectedClients.title: Don't open a new connection for every request / every command

content.value: When the value of your connected_clients is high, it usually means that your application is opening and closing a connection for every request it makes. Opening a connection is an expensive operation that adds to both client and server latency.
l
To rectify this, consult your Redis clientâ€™s documentation and configure it to use persistent connections.

searchString.title: Optimize your query and search experience

content.value: Storing large strings (> 512 KB) could consume more resources and time to process, manipulate, update, and retrieve them. Consider representing your data using hashes or use RedisJSON to store your JSON documents to improve performance.
l

Sets that contain only integers are extremely efficient memory-wise. Try to use integers by mapping string identifiers to integers. You can either use enums in your programming language or Redis hashes to map values to integers.
l
If you choose hashes, you can use RediSearch, designed to help address your query needs and supports a better development experience.

If you usually update sub-elements of your JSON document instead of retrieving and writing the entire document, use RedisJSON to store your JSON documents instead of strings to improve the performance and decrease the code complexity.

With RedisJSON you also can use RediSearch with support for indexing and querying the content of JSON documents.
